questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician after she accidentally cut her right forearm earlier that morning while working with her mother's embroidery scissors. She has no history of serious illness. The mother says she went to elementary and middle school abroad and is not sure if she received all of her childhood vaccinations. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6 °F), pulse 90/min, and blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a clean 2-cm laceration on her right forearm with surrounding edema. There is no erythema or discharge. The wound is irrigated with water and washed with soap. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

DTaP is the vaccine preparation of choice for the primary immunization schedule as well as for postexposure prophylaxis in children between the ages of 6 weeks and 7 years. In a 14-year-old patient with a clean, minor wound and an unknown immunization history, active immunization is required. However, a different preparation suited for active immunization in older children is required, since DTaP is not indicated for postexposure prophylaxis in children older than 7 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is effective against anaerobic bacteria, including Clostridium tetani, which causes tetanus. Intravenous metronidazole is used along with tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) to treat acute tetanus infection. Metronidazole does not play a role in postexposure prophylaxis.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with a clean, minor wound and an unknown immunization history, active immunization with Tdap is required. If the wound was neither clean nor minor, Tdap should otherwise be combined with TIG.

See “Tetanus prophylaxis after injury” table.

D) INCORRECT:

A combination of tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) and Tdap is used for postexposure prophylaxis in individuals with an unknown immunization history who have wounds that are neither clean nor minor. TIG is not indicated for clean wounds, as is the case with this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used for postexposure prophylaxis in combination with active immunization in individuals with an unknown immunization history who have wounds that are neither clean nor minor. TIG is not indicated for clean wounds, nor should it be administered alone (i.e., only passive immunization) in any patient older than 6 weeks of age.

Passive immunization on its own (only TIG) is indicated for postexposure prophylaxis in infants less than 6 weeks of age with a dirty, contaminated wound, since active immunization with the tetanus toxoid is not recommended for this age group.

F) INCORRECT:

Tetanus has a high mortality rate (10%) even with early, aggressive treatment. Therefore, prevention of tetanus via postexposure prophylaxis is always required in a patient with any wound and an unknown immunization history. If a patient has a clean, minor wound and had received ≥ 3 tetanus toxoid doses with the last dose less than 10 years ago, no further steps would be required
questions.hint: This patient has a clean, minor wound and her immunization status against tetanus is unknown.

questions.text: A previously healthy 10-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of episodes of weakness and spasms for the past 12 hours. His mother states that he has also had difficulty feeding and opening his mouth. He has not had fever, cough, diarrhea, or vomiting. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery at home. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. The mother refused prenatal vaccines out of concern they would cause side effects. She is worried his symptoms may be from some raw honey his older sister may have inadvertently fed him 5 days ago. He appears irritable. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). Examination shows generalized muscle stiffness and twitches. His fontanelles are soft and flat. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clostridium botulinum produces a neurotoxin that causes infant botulism, a neuroparalytic syndrome that manifests with weakness, poor feeding, and irritability. It is associated with the ingestion of honey products contaminated with C. botulinum. The raw honey that the infant possibly ingested may have been a potential source of the disease, but this infant presents with muscle stiffness instead of hypotony, which is not consistent with botulism.
Image Description:

This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

B) CORRECT:

Clostridium tetani produce an exotoxin (tetanospasmin) that inhibits neurotransmission, causing neonatal tetanus, a life-threatening condition characterized by muscle spasms, myoclonus, irritability, and poor feeding. Tetanus is acquired in nonimmunized individuals after spores of the pathogen enter the body through broken skin. Neonatal tetanus most commonly results from unsterile management of the umbilical stump, which is more likely to occur in resource-limited regions or after home births. The tetanus vaccine is routinely administered in pregnancy, which allows the newborn to acquire passive immunity through maternal antibodies that cross the placenta and be protected until the regular tetanus vaccine (at 2 months of age) is administered. Infants born to nonimmunized patients are especially at high risk of developing neonatal tetanus.

Tetanus may cause respiratory muscle spasms, leading to respiratory failure. The toxin reaches the CNS via retrograde axonal transport, where it blocks the release of neurotransmitters. Because the axonal length of neurotransmitters is shorter in children than in adults, children exhibit a rapid onset of symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis is a gram-negative diplococcus that causes bacterial meningitis primarily in older children and adults. It is also a possible cause of neonatal bacterial meningitis, but other microorganisms (such as group B Streptococcus and Escherichia coli) are more common. Neonatal meningitis presents with irritability, poor feeding, fever, and a bulging fontanelle. However, this patient presents with a soft and flat fontanelle and has not had a fever. Generalized muscle stiffness and spasms would also not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacteria that can cause neonatal meningitis, which typically manifests with irritability, poor feeding, fever, and bulging fontanelles. However, this patient presents with a soft and flat fontanelle and has not had a fever. Listeria also does not cause muscle spasms and stiffness, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative rod that can cause neonatal meningitis, which typically manifests with irritability, poor feeding, fever, and bulging fontanelles. However, this patient presents with a soft and flat fontanelle and has not had a fever. E. coli also does not cause muscle spasms and stiffness, making it an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by uncontrolled activation of alpha motor neurons.

questions.text: A 5-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of poor feeding, irritability, and noisy breathing. The mother did not receive any prenatal care. His respirations are 26/min. Physical examination shows sunken fontanelles, tightly clenched fists, and erythema around the umbilical cord stump. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the disease process in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infant botulism is due to ingestion of botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum. The toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine from the neuromuscular junction (NMJ) and causes muscle paralysis. Although infant botulism also manifests with breathing difficulty, poor feeding, and irritability, it causes descending flaccid paralysis, while this patient has spastic paralysis.
Image Description:

This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of voltage-gated sodium channels in the nervous system can occur shortly after ingestion of seafood that is contaminated with tetrodotoxin or ciguatoxin. These neurotoxin blocks the formation of action potentials in neurons and thereby blocks neural signals from passing to muscles. Tetrodotoxin or ciguatoxin poisoning would not be expected in this 5-day-old neonate who has not yet been weaned.

C) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is a postinfectious autoimmune reaction in which molecular mimicry results in formation of antiganglioside antibodies and subsequent destruction of Schwann cells. GBS causes ascending flaccid paralysis rather than spastic paralysis (tightly clenched fists).

D) CORRECT:

Neonatal tetanus is caused by tetanospasmin, which is produced by ubiquitous Clostridium tetani spores that then contaminate wounds (e.g., umbilical cord). The toxin reaches the CNS via retrograde axonal transport and blocks the release of glycine and GABA from inhibitory interneurons (Renshaw cells). This causes uncontrolled activation of alpha motor neurons, which results in tonic and clonic spasms (difficulty opening the mouth and feeding due to trismus, clenched hands). The most effective measure to prevent neonatal tetanus is immunization of women who are pregnant or of childbearing age. Vaccinated women produce antibodies against tetanospasmin that can cross the placenta, which provided passive immunity for the neonate.

E) INCORRECT:

Poliomyelitis is a viral disease that causes destruction of anterior horn cells. Although difficulty breathing, poor feeding, and irritability are clinical features of poliomyelitis, it causes ascending flaccid paralysis rather than the spastic paralysis (tightly clenched fists) seen in this patient. Furthermore, poliomyelitis has been eradicated from the United States and most other countries due to widespread vaccination.
questions.hint: This newborn has several risk factors (lack of maternal prenatal care, umbilical cord stump infection) that should raise concern for neonatal tetanus.

questions.text: An investigator is studying central nervous system neurotransmitters in mice. He injects the spinal cord with a protease that cleaves SNARE proteins, thereby blocking the release of neurotransmitters from the Renshaw cells in the spinal cord. Which of the following consequences would be expected?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disinhibited behavior can occur in several neurological diseases, including HSV encephalitis or frontotemporal dementia. Disinhibited behavior is not related to the cleavage of SNARE proteins.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrophobia is a classic symptom of rabies. The rabies virus travels from the bite wound retrograde along the peripheral nerves towards the CNS. The pathogenesis of rabies is not fully understood, but experimental studies have postulated a potential involvement of acetylcholine receptors. There is no known association with SNARE proteins or proteases.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive Kernig sign can be caused by meningeal irritation, a typical feature of meningitis. Other symptoms of meningitis include headache, fever, and altered mental status. It is most commonly caused by a viral or bacterial infection (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis in adult patients). There is no known association with SNARE proteins or proteases.
Image Description:

The Kernig sign can be assessed using two methods. In the first method (A), the extended leg is passively elevated at the hip joint. If there is pain, there is reflex flexion of the knee. Alternatively (B), the Kernig sign can be assessed by flexing the hip and knee at a 90° angle. Subsequent extension of the leg causes stretching of the nerve roots or meninges, which can result in pain and muscle guarding against extension.

D) CORRECT:

The mechanism of action of the substance described is consistent with tetanospasmin, which cleaves SNARE proteins (e.g., synaptobrevin, syntaxin) and thereby prevents the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters from Renshaw cells. Injection with protease would lead to uncontrolled activation of alpha motor neurons, causing spastic paralysis, trismus, risus sardonicus, and opisthotonus. Another neurotoxin that acts through the cleavage of SNARE proteins is botulinum toxin, which acts peripherally at the neuromuscular junctions and prevents the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft. The resulting clinical manifestation is a peripheral flaccid muscle paralysis that descends caudally.

E) INCORRECT:

An ascending flaccid paralysis is a typical finding in Guillain-Barré syndrome, which results from an autoimmune reaction mediated by cross-reactive antibodies against Schwann cells (e.g., following an infection with C. jejuni) and subsequent demyelination. No proteases are involved in ascending flaccid paralysis, and it is not related to the cleavage of SNARE proteins.
questions.hint: Some neurotoxins released by bacteria are proteolytic enzymes that cause a disruption of neuronal function. This particular neurotoxin also causes risus sardonicus and opisthotonus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of an open wound on her left knee after falling while crossing a creek during a hike about 3 hours ago. She hit her knee on a rock and then had to crawl on the ground for several meters until help arrived. She does not recall her immunization status. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a swollen and tender left knee; range of motion is limited by pain. There is a 5x3-cm (1.9x1.2-in) laceration just below the left kneecap; the skin is partly attached on the tibial side. The wound is covered with dirt and soil; there is erythema around the wound margins. The wound is thoroughly irrigated and debrided. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Tension-free apposition of wound edges and administration of tetanus immunoglobulin
Surgical treatment with skin flap transfer and administration of tetanus immunoglobulin
Administration of tetanus immunoglobulin and tetanus vaccine
Administration of oral antibiotics and tetanus vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary wound closure using tension-free apposition of wound edges is routinely performed for minor, clean open wounds. This patient, however, has a contaminated wound, for which primary wound closure is contraindicated. Moreover, as this patient has an unclear vaccination status, it is not sufficient to only administer tetanus immunoglobulin.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical treatment with a skin flap transfer is indicated in wounds with extensive tissue loss, for which other methods of wound management (e.g., primary wound closure, secondary wound closure, skin grafting) are not possible or yield unsatisfactory results. A different method of wound closure is preferred for this patient, who has a minor but contaminated laceration. Moreover, as this patient has an unclear vaccination status, it is not sufficient to only administer tetanus immunoglobulin.

C) INCORRECT:

In the case of a dirty wound, as seen here, tetanus prevention with active immunization (tetanus vaccine) alone is sufficient for patients who have an up-to-date immunization status with the last booster tetanus vaccine being administered more than 5 years ago. This patient, however, has an unclear vaccination status and therefore requires another time-sensitive step in addition to active immunization.

D) CORRECT:

Both passive immunization (tetanus immunoglobulin) and active immunization (tetanus vaccine) are indicated for patients with dirty wounds and incomplete or unclear tetanus immunization status, as seen here. Passive immunization is necessary to rapidly neutralize C. tetani exotoxins. Active immunization with Td or Tdap prevents tetanus, and the vaccine should be administered every 10 years in all individuals. In addition to immunization, the wound should be cleaned thoroughly and any devitalized tissue that is present should be removed. The minor, contaminated laceration in this patient should be treated with secondary or tertiary wound closure; primary wound closure is contraindicated. For wounds with a high risk of infection, e.g., those with contaminated wounds in relatively poorly vascularized areas (like the knee), similar to what is seen here, oral antibiotic therapy for the prevention of wound infection is also recommended.

See “Tetanus prophylaxis after injury” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotic therapy for the prevention of wound infection is recommended for contaminated wounds in relatively poorly vascularized areas (e.g., around the knee), and this patient, who has an unclear vaccination status, does require the tetanus vaccine. However, a different time-sensitive step is more important and should be performed immediately.

Systemic antibiotic therapy is indicated for a wound infection. This patient's laceration is contaminated but the swelling and wound margin erythema are the early inflammatory changes that occur following injury, and not the result of wound infection. Wound infection is unlikely to occur within 3 hours.
questions.hint: If this patient is not current on her immunizations, her contaminated wound makes her susceptible to lockjaw and life-threatening spasms of the laryngeal and diaphragmatic muscles.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States presents to the emergency department with his grandmother for evaluation of a forearm wound that occurred yesterday while he was using a nail gun for a construction project. His grandmother is unsure of his immunization history, and records are not available.
His vital signs are normal, but he appears anxious. Examination of his forearm reveals a deep puncture wound that is warm and tender, with surrounding erythema. No other injuries are evident.
The wound is irrigated and debrided, a dressing is applied, and antibiotics are administered.
Which one of the following tetanus regimens is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccine, plus tetanus immune globulin
Tetanus-diphtheria vaccine, plus tetanus immune globulin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The optimal regimen for tetanus prophylaxis depends on the patient’s vaccination history. Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG).

B) INCORRECT:

The optimal regimen for tetanus prophylaxis depends on the patient’s vaccination history. Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG). A single dose of tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is preferable to tetanus-diphtheria (Td) vaccine for all individuals aged ≥10 years who have not previously received Tdap or whose immunization history is unknown.

C) CORRECT:

Tetanus is a disease caused by a wound infection with Clostridium tetani. Most wounds are considered “dirty” and prone to tetanus, including contaminated wounds, burns, animal bites, all puncture wounds, and even some clean wounds.

Once a wound has been irrigated and (if necessary) debrided, appropriate tetanus prophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible. Because the incubation period for infection varies, from one day to several months, postexposure prophylaxis should be given even to patients who present late for medical attention. The optimal regimen for tetanus prophylaxis depends on the patient’s vaccination history. See “Postexposure tetanus prophylaxis” table.

Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG). TIG is given intramuscularly in one extremity while the tetanus vaccine is given in another extremity. Intravenous TIG should be administered if intramuscular TIG is not available. A single dose of tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is preferable to tetanus-diphtheria (Td) vaccine for all individuals aged ≥10 years who have not previously received Tdap or whose immunization history is unknown, as is the case for this 18-year-old patient. However, Td may be given if Tdap is not available.

Key learning point: A young adult with an unknown vaccine history who presents with a dirty wound should receive tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccine, plus tetanus immune globulin.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG). A single dose of tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is preferable to tetanus-diphtheria (Td) vaccine for all individuals aged ≥10 years who have not previously received Tdap or whose immunization history is unknown.

E) INCORRECT:

The optimal regimen for tetanus prophylaxis depends on the patient’s vaccination history. Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG).

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy who recently immigrated to the United States presents to the emergency department with his grandmother for evaluation of a forearm wound that occurred yesterday while he was using a nail gun for a construction project. His grandmother is unsure of his immunization history, and records are not available.
His vital signs are normal, but he appears anxious. Examination of his forearm reveals a deep puncture wound that is warm and tender, with surrounding erythema. No other injuries are evident.
The wound is irrigated and debrided, a dressing is applied, and antibiotics are administered.
Which one of the following tetanus regimens is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccine, plus tetanus immune globulin
Tetanus-diphtheria vaccine, plus tetanus immune globulin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG).

B) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG). A single dose of tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is preferable to tetanus-diphtheria (Td) vaccine for all individuals aged ≥10 years who have not previously received Tdap or whose immunization history is unknown, as is the case for this 15-year-old patient.

C) CORRECT:

Tetanus is a disease caused by a wound infection with Clostridium tetani. Most wounds are considered prone to tetanus, including contaminated wounds, burns, animal bites, all puncture wounds, and even some clean wounds.

Once a wound has been irrigated and (if necessary) debrided, appropriate tetanus prophylaxis should be administered as soon as possible. Because the incubation period for infection varies, from one day to several months, postexposure prophylaxis should be given even to patients who present late for medical attention. The optimal regimen for tetanus prophylaxis depends on the patient’s vaccination history and age. See “Postexposure tetanus prophylaxis” table.

Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG). TIG is given intramuscularly in one extremity while the tetanus vaccine is given in another extremity. Intravenous TIG should be administered if intramuscular TIG is not available. A single dose of tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is preferable to tetanus-diphtheria (Td) vaccine for all individuals aged ≥10 years who have not previously received Tdap or whose immunization history is unknown, as is the case for this 15-year-old patient. However, Td may be given if Tdap is not available. Tdap is also recommended for children aged 7 to 10 years who have not received the full five-dose series of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine.

Key learning point: A patient with an unknown vaccine history who presents with a dirty wound should receive tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccine, plus tetanus immune globulin.

D) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG).

E) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has a dirty wound and an unknown vaccination history, he should receive both a tetanus vaccine and tetanus immune globulin (TIG). However, a single dose of tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is preferable to tetanus-diphtheria (Td) vaccine for all individuals aged ≥10 years who have not previously received Tdap or whose immunization history is unknown, as is the case for this 15-year-old patient. Td may be given if Tdap is not available. Tdap is also recommended for children aged 7 to 10 years who have not received the full five-dose series of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the office after she accidentally cut her right forearm while working with her mother's embroidery scissors. The mother says she went to elementary and middle school abroad and is not sure if she received all of her childhood vaccinations. Temperature is 37°C (98.6 °F), pulse 90/min, and blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a clean 2-cm laceration on her right forearm with surrounding edema. There is no erythema or discharge. The wound is irrigated with water and washed with soap. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

DTaP is the vaccine preparation of choice for the primary immunization schedule as well as for postexposure prophylaxis in children between the ages of 6 weeks and 7 years. In a 14-year-old patient with a clean, minor wound and an unknown immunization history, active immunization is required. However, a different preparation suited for active immunization in older children is required, since DTaP is not indicated for postexposure prophylaxis in children older than 7 years of age.

B) CORRECT:

In a patient with a clean, minor wound and an unknown immunization history, active immunization with Tdap is required. If the wound was neither clean nor minor, Tdap should otherwise be combined with TIG.

See “Tetanus prophylaxis after injury” table.

Key learning point: For a clean, minor wound with unknown tetanus immunization status in patients aged 7 years and older, administer a single dose of Tdap for active immunization.

C) INCORRECT:

A combination of tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) and Tdap is used for postexposure prophylaxis in individuals with an unknown immunization history who have wounds that are neither clean nor minor. TIG is not indicated for clean wounds, as is the case with this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used for postexposure prophylaxis in combination with active immunization in individuals with an unknown immunization history who have wounds that are neither clean nor minor. TIG is not indicated for clean wounds, nor should it be administered alone (i.e., only passive immunization) in any patient older than 6 weeks of age.

Passive immunization on its own (only TIG) is indicated for postexposure prophylaxis in infants less than 6 weeks of age with a dirty, contaminated wound, since active immunization with the tetanus toxoid is not recommended for this age group.

E) INCORRECT:

Tetanus has a high mortality rate (10%) even with early, aggressive treatment. Therefore, prevention of tetanus via postexposure prophylaxis is always required in a patient with any wound and an unknown immunization history. If a patient has a clean, minor wound and had received ≥ 3 tetanus toxoid doses with the last dose less than 10 years ago, no further steps would be required
questions.hint: This patient has a clean, minor wound and her immunization status against tetanus is unknown.

Generalized muscle stiffness and spasms would also not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacteria that can cause neonatal meningitis, which typically manifests with irritability, poor feeding, fever, and bulging fontanelles. However, this patient presents with a soft and flat fontanelle and has not had a fever. Listeria also does not cause muscle spasms and stiffness, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative rod that can cause neonatal meningitis, which typically manifests with irritability, poor feeding, fever, and bulging fontanelles. However, this patient presents with a soft and flat fontanelle and has not had a fever. E. coli also does not cause muscle spasms and stiffness, making it an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by uncontrolled activation of alpha motor neurons.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to your clinic after accidentally cutting her right forearm with her mother's embroidery scissors. Her mother reports that the patient attended elementary and middle school abroad and is unsure if she received all of her childhood vaccinations. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg. Examination reveals a clean 2-cm laceration on the right forearm with surrounding edema, but no erythema or discharge. The wound is irrigated with water and washed with soap. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A combination of tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) and Tdap is used for postexposure prophylaxis in individuals with an unknown immunization history who have wounds that are neither clean nor minor. TIG is not indicated for clean wounds, as is the case with this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used for postexposure prophylaxis in combination with active immunization in individuals with an unknown immunization history who have wounds that are neither clean nor minor. TIG is not indicated for clean wounds, nor should it be administered alone (i.e., only passive immunization) in any patient older than 6 weeks of age.

Passive immunization on its own (only TIG) is indicated for postexposure prophylaxis in infants less than 6 weeks of age with a dirty, contaminated wound, since active immunization with the tetanus toxoid is not recommended for this age group.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with a clean, minor wound and an unknown immunization history, active immunization with Tdap is required. If the wound was neither clean nor minor, Tdap should otherwise be combined with TIG.

See “Tetanus prophylaxis after injury” table.

Key learning point: For a clean, minor wound with unknown tetanus immunization status in patients aged 7 years and older, administer a single dose of Tdap for active immunization.

D) INCORRECT:

Tetanus has a high mortality rate (10%) even with early, aggressive treatment. Therefore, prevention of tetanus via postexposure prophylaxis is always required in a patient with any wound and an unknown immunization history. If a patient has a clean, minor wound and had received ≥ 3 tetanus toxoid doses with the last dose less than 10 years ago, no further steps would be required

E) INCORRECT:

DTaP is the vaccine preparation of choice for the primary immunization schedule as well as for postexposure prophylaxis in children between the ages of 6 weeks and 7 years. In a 14-year-old patient with a clean, minor wound and an unknown immunization history, active immunization is required. However, a different preparation suited for active immunization in older children is required, since DTaP is not indicated for postexposure prophylaxis in children older than 7 years of age.
questions.hint: This patient has a clean, minor wound and her immunization status against tetanus is unknown.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old boy in the emergency department who presents with a 1-day history of involuntary muscle contractions and pain in his back and neck. Two weeks ago, he fell while playing in a sandbox and scraped his knees. He has not received any vaccinations since birth. His temperature is 38.5°C. He is diaphoretic. On examination, he is unable to open his mouth beyond 1 cm, has hyperextension of the lumbar spine, and shows resistance to neck flexion. Which one of the following, if administered, would most likely have prevented his current condition?

choices.text: Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Denatured C. tetani toxoid is used as a vaccination against tetanus. The still-intact receptor binding site of the toxoid induces antibody production and memory cell formation (active immunity). In patients with dirty wounds and incomplete or unclear tetanus immunization status, postexposure prophylaxis should include vaccination with DTaP and administration of human tetanus immunoglobulin (HTIG). Management of tetanus includes antibiotic therapy and intensive care treatment.

Key learning point: The tetanus vaccine is a denatured (inactivated) bacterial toxoid that induces active immunity and prevents tetanus infection.
Image Description:

This diagram illustrates vaccine types based on the example of antiviral vaccines.

Traditional vaccines are either live attenuated or inactivated. Live attenuated vaccines contain modified whole virus particles capable of replication, but not of causing disease. Inactivated vaccines contain either the whole inactivated virus particles or their subunits.

Gene-based vaccines contain only the genetic information of the pathogen. This information, which is transmitted either directly in the form of nucleic acid (DNA in a recombinant plasmid or mRNA in a lipid envelope) or by means of a recombinant viral vector, induces endogenous antigen production in the host cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Capsular polysaccharide vaccines contain purified capsule antigens that are usually conjugated to a carrier protein (conjugate vaccine). Such vaccines are used to prevent infection with, e.g., S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b, and N. meningitidis, all of which can cause meningitis. Although meningitis can present with fever and neck stiffness, trismus and opisthotonus are not characteristic features. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

C) INCORRECT:

Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein is used for post-exposure prophylaxis in suspected cases of rabies. Administering preformed antibodies provides a passive immunity that, however, does not last long due to the antibodies' short half-life. Even though patients with rabies can present with trismus, opisthotonus, and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity, as seen in this patient, they also present with other characteristic features like hydrophobia and agitation. Furthermore, this patient has no history of an animal bite (e.g., by a bat or raccoon) that would raise suspicion for transmission of rabies. In post-exposure prophylaxis of tetanus, which is caused by a bacterium, not a virus, human tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used against tetanus toxin.

D) INCORRECT:

Chemically-inactivated (whole-cell) viruses have been used as vaccines to prevent, e.g., polio (Salk vaccine), hepatitis A, and influenza virus infections. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

E) INCORRECT:

Viable but weakened microorganisms are used in live attenuated vaccines for the prevention of, e.g., measles, mumps, rubella, varicella zoster, and rotavirus infection. These vaccines induce both cellular and humoral immune responses. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.
questions.hint: Generalized muscle spasms (trismus, mild opisthotonus, nuchal rigidity) and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity (fever, sweating) following a cutaneous injury in an unvaccinated child suggest tetanus, which is diagnosed clinically.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of progressive muscle stiffness. Eight days ago, he sustained a deep laceration to his forearm while repairing farm equipment. His vaccination history is unknown. On examination, he has facial muscle spasms creating a fixed grimace and intermittent back arching. His vital signs are normal. Which of the following is the most important initial intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical features of risus sardonicus, opisthotonus, and a recent contaminated wound are consistent with tetanus. Diazepam is used to manage severe muscle spasms in tetanus. However, this patient's symptoms are not severe enough to warrant benzodiazepines before targeted therapy for the disease.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical features of risus sardonicus, opisthotonus, and a recent contaminated wound are consistent with tetanus. Metronidazole is the preferred antibiotic for tetanus treatment, but it is not the most urgent initial intervention.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical features of risus sardonicus, opisthotonus, and a recent contaminated wound are consistent with tetanus. Human tetanus immunoglobulin should be administered as soon as possible. The immunoglobulin neutralizes free tetanus toxins and prevents further toxin binding to nerve endings, slowing disease progression.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical features of risus sardonicus, opisthotonus, and a recent contaminated wound are consistent with tetanus. Active immunization with the tetanus vaccine is important, but the vaccine should be administered after passive immunization, once the patient is improving.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical features of risus sardonicus, opisthotonus, and a recent contaminated wound are consistent with tetanus. Invasive airway management may become necessary if the patient develops trismus, laryngospasm, or respiratory muscle spasms. However, this patient currently has normal vital signs and no signs of respiratory compromise.

questions.text: A 52-year-old farmer presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of progressive muscle stiffness and difficulty opening the mouth. The patient reports cleaning a barn 2 weeks ago and recalls stepping on something sharp. Physical examination shows limited jaw opening, facial muscle rigidity with a fixed grin expression, and neck stiffness. Vitals are R, 24; oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. During the examination, a loud noise triggers sudden muscle spasms throughout the patient's body. What is the most appropriate initial management step?

choices.text: Obtain wound cultures and perform debridement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Human tetanus immunoglobulin is essential for neutralizing free toxins and should be administered promptly in tetanus. The immunoglobulin binds to unbound tetanus toxin and prevents further progression of the disease. However, in this patient at high risk of airway compromise, airway management is the more immediate priority.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is the preferred antibiotic for tetanus to reduce bacterial load and toxin production. Antibiotic therapy helps eliminate vegetative bacteria and reduce ongoing toxin release from the wound site. However, in this patient at high risk of airway compromise, another step is the more immediate priority.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has a high risk for laryngospasm and respiratory muscle involvement based on signs of generalized tetanus with stimulus-triggered spasms. Airway management with rapid sequence intubation should be prepared immediately, as trismus and laryngospasm can make intubation extremely difficult once respiratory compromise occurs.

D) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines are indicated to manage severe muscle spasms in tetanus and may help control stimulus-triggered contractions, but in a patient with such a high risk of airway compromise, airway management is the priority. Once the airway is secure, lorazepam can reduce muscle rigidity and provide sedation to improve ventilation and prevent patient-ventilator dyssynchrony.

E) INCORRECT:

Wound debridement is important to reduce the bacterial load and decrease ongoing toxin production. Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue and foreign material helps eliminate the source of continued toxin release. However, in this patient at high risk of airway compromise, airway management is the more immediate priority.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a 3-cm laceration on her forearm sustained while gardening with soil-contaminated tools. She received her primary tetanus series in childhood and recalls getting a tetanus booster 8 years ago when she stepped on a nail. She takes methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis and has well-controlled HIV infection with an undetectable viral load. What is the most appropriate tetanus prophylaxis?

choices.text: Defer prophylaxis pending tetanus antibody levels
Both tetanus vaccine and human tetanus immune globulin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tetanus antibody levels are not routinely measured for postexposure prophylaxis decisions. Management is based on vaccination history, wound characteristics, and level of immune system function. Deferring prophylaxis could result in inadequate protection for this high-risk patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetanus prophylaxis is indicated for this patient. The 8-year interval since her last vaccine exceeds the 5-year threshold for tetanus-prone wounds, and she needs extra protection based on her HIV infection and immunosuppression from methotrexate.

C) INCORRECT:

Human tetanus immune globulin alone provides only passive immunity and does not stimulate active antibody production. This patient is high risk, and her last dose was > 5 years ago. Human tetanus immune globulin alone is insufficient to boost active immunity.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has a tetanus-prone wound, HIV infection, and immunocompromise due to methotrexate use. While the tetanus vaccine is indicated since her last dose was over 5 years ago, active immunization alone is insufficient for her risk category.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has a tetanus-prone wound, and her last vaccine was > 5 years ago. She also has an HIV infection and is immunocompromised due to methotrexate therapy. Both the tetanus vaccine and human tetanus immune globulin are indicated, regardless of vaccination history, in patients with HIV infection or severe immunodeficiency.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for difficulty opening his mouth and swallowing. One week ago, he sustained a puncture wound on his foot from a rusty nail. His vaccination history is incomplete. On examination, he is irritable and has sustained spasms of his facial muscles. He is afebrile with normal vital signs. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Passive neck flexion causing hip flexion
Descending paralysis starting with the eyelids
Ascending paralysis starting in the legs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This describes the Brudzinski sign, which indicates meningeal irritation and is most commonly seen in bacterial meningitis. Although this patient is irritable, a finding also seen in meningitis, his other symptoms, such as trismus and facial spasms, are not characteristic of meningitis. Tetanus affects motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem but does not typically cause meningeal inflammation.

B) INCORRECT:

Unilateral facial drooping indicates a flaccid paralysis of the muscles of facial expression, which is characteristic of a peripheral facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) palsy, such as Bell palsy. Tetanus causes spastic contraction of the facial muscles, typically bilaterally, resulting in a grimace known as risus sardonicus, not a unilateral flaccid paralysis.

C) INCORRECT:

A descending, symmetric flaccid paralysis is the hallmark of botulism, which is caused by a neurotoxin that blocks acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction. This patient presents with spasticity and muscle spasms, which is the opposite of the flaccid paralysis seen in botulism. Although both conditions are caused by clostridial toxins, their mechanisms of action and clinical presentations are distinct.

D) INCORRECT:

A symmetric ascending flaccid paralysis is the classic presentation of Guillain-Barré syndrome, an acute autoimmune inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy. This condition is characterized by weakness and areflexia, which contrasts with the hypertonia, rigidity, and spasms seen in tetanus. The underlying pathophysiology involves immune-mediated nerve damage, not a bacterial neurotoxin.

E) CORRECT:

Opisthotonos, a severe arching of the back due to powerful spasms of the paraspinal extensor muscles, is a characteristic and life-threatening manifestation of severe tetanus. Tetanus is caused by the neurotoxin tetanospasmin, released by Clostridium tetani after contamination of a wound, such as a puncture injury. The toxin blocks the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (gamma-aminobutyric acid and glycine) in the spinal cord, leading to unopposed motor neuron firing and severe muscle spasms. Initial symptoms of tetanus include trismus (lockjaw) and risus sardonicus (a sustained facial muscle spasm). As the disease progresses, it affects larger muscle groups, causing generalized rigidity and reflex spasms.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is highly suggestive of generalized tetanus.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of involuntary muscle contractions and pain in his back and neck. Two weeks ago, he fell while playing in the sandbox and scraped his knees. He has not received any vaccinations since birth. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). He is diaphoretic. Examination shows inability to open his mouth beyond 1 cm. There is hyperextension of the lumbar spine and resistance to neck flexion. Administration of which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Capsular polysaccharide vaccines contain purified capsule antigens that are usually conjugated to a carrier protein (conjugate vaccine). Such vaccines are used to prevent infection with, e.g., S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b, and N. meningitidis, all of which can cause meningitis. Although meningitis can present with fever and neck stiffness, trismus and opisthotonus are not characteristic features. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

B) INCORRECT:

Chemically-inactivated (whole-cell) viruses have been used as vaccines to prevent, e.g., polio (Salk vaccine), hepatitis A, and influenza virus infections. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

C) CORRECT:

Denatured C. tetani toxoid is used as a vaccination against tetanus. The still-intact receptor binding site of the toxoid induces antibody production and memory cell formation (active immunity). In patients with dirty wounds and incomplete or unclear tetanus immunization status, postexposure prophylaxis should include vaccination with DTaP and administration of human tetanus immunoglobulin (HTIG). Management of tetanus includes antibiotic therapy and intensive care treatment.
Image Description:

This diagram illustrates vaccine types based on the example of antiviral vaccines.

Traditional vaccines are either live attenuated or inactivated. Live attenuated vaccines contain modified whole virus particles capable of replication, but not of causing disease. Inactivated vaccines contain either the whole inactivated virus particles or their subunits.

Gene-based vaccines contain only the genetic information of the pathogen. This information, which is transmitted either directly in the form of nucleic acid (DNA in a recombinant plasmid or mRNA in a lipid envelope) or by means of a recombinant viral vector, induces endogenous antigen production in the host cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein is used for post-exposure prophylaxis in suspected cases of rabies. Administering preformed antibodies provides a passive immunity that, however, does not last long due to the antibodies' short half-life. Even though patients with rabies can present with trismus, opisthotonus, and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity, as seen in this patient, they also present with other characteristic features like hydrophobia and agitation. Furthermore, this patient has no history of an animal bite (e.g., by a bat or raccoon) that would raise suspicion for transmission of rabies. In post-exposure prophylaxis of tetanus, which is caused by a bacterium, not a virus, human tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used against tetanus toxin.

E) INCORRECT:

Viable but weakened microorganisms are used in live attenuated vaccines for the prevention of, e.g., measles, mumps, rubella, varicella zoster, and rotavirus infection. These vaccines induce both cellular and humoral immune responses. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.
questions.hint: Generalized muscle spasms (trismus, mild opisthotonus, nuchal rigidity) and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity (fever, sweating) following a cutaneous injury in an unvaccinated child suggest tetanus, which is diagnosed clinically.
